head.title: Photoswitchable Surfactant-Driven Reversible Shape- and Color-Changing Block Copolymer Particles | Journal of the American Chemical Society

meta.content: Photoswitchable Surfactant-Driven Reversible Shape- and Color-Changing Block Copolymer Particles

Polymer particles that switch their shape and color in response to light are of great interest for the development of programmable smart materials. Herein, we report block copolymer (BCP) particles with reversible shapes and colors activated by irradiation with ultraviolet (UV) and visible lights. This shape transformation of the BCP particles is achieved by a spiropyran-dodecyltrimethylammoium bromide (SP-DTAB) surfactant that changes its amphiphilicity upon photoisomerization. Under UV light (365 nm) irradiation, the hydrophilic ring-opened merocyanine form of the SP-DTAB surfactant affords the formation of spherical, onion-like BCP particles. In contrast, when exposed to visible light, surfactants with the ring-closed form yield prolate or oblate BCP ellipsoids with axially stacked nanostructures. Importantly, the change in BCP particle morphology between spheres and ellipsoids is reversible over multiple UV and visible light irradiation cycles. In addition, the shape- and color-switchable BCP particles are integrated to form a composite hydrogel, demonstrating their potential as high-resolution displays with reversible patterning capabilities.

div.p: Polymer particles that switch their shape and color in response to light are of great interest for the development of programmable smart materials. Herein, we report block copolymer (BCP) particles with reversible shapes and colors activated by irradiation with ultraviolet (UV) and visible lights. This shape transformation of the BCP particles is achieved by a spiropyran-dodecyltrimethylammoium bromide (SP-DTAB) surfactant that changes its amphiphilicity upon photoisomerization. Under UV light (365 nm) irradiation, the hydrophilic ring-opened merocyanine form of the SP-DTAB surfactant affords the formation of spherical, onion-like BCP particles. In contrast, when exposed to visible light, surfactants with the ring-closed form yield prolate or oblate BCP ellipsoids with axially stacked nanostructures. Importantly, the change in BCP particle morphology between spheres and ellipsoids is reversible over multiple UV and visible light irradiation cycles. In addition, the shape- and color-switchable BCP particles are integrated to form a composite hydrogel, demonstrating their potential as high-resolution displays with reversible patterning capabilities.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Shape-transformable particles are highly promising smart materials due to their switchable optical properties,
(1,2)
rheological behavior,
(3â6)
and cellular interactions.
(7)
The integration of stimuli-responsive functional groups into polymer particles allows one to systematically control the morphology of the particles that respond to physical, chemical, or biological stimuli.
(8)
In particular, photoresponsive materials have gathered significant interest due to the superior spatial and temporal resolution of light.
(9â11)
Moreover, a high level of the controllability of light-responsive behavior can be achieved by varying optical wavelengths, intensities, and chemical structures of the photoresponsive groups.
(12â14)
However, there has been a limited number of reports on light-responsive particles with well-defined shapes and nanostructures.
(15,16)

One potential strategy to develop particles that change shape in response to light is to employ photoresponsive polymers and surfactant molecules that modulate the surface properties of the particles upon light irradiation. Given that the soft and mobile interface of an emulsion droplet allows the spontaneous deformation of the particle shape, the self-assembly of block copolymers (BCPs) confined in an emulsion has been utilized to produce shape-transforming particles.
(17â24)
This method allows for the large-scale production of uniform BCP particles with tunable shapes and nanostructures.
(25â37)
Recently, our group reported BCP particles that change shape in response to light by using surfactants bearing photocleavable groups (i.e., nitrobenzyl esters and coumarin esters).
(15)
However, photocleavage in the surfactant is irreversible, limiting their utilization in industrial applications that require reversible properties. Alternatively, photoswitchable units that undergo structural isomerization upon irradiation are promising building blocks for constructing reversible light-responsive materials.
(38â43)
For example, azobenzene moieties have been incorporated into spherical polymer particles that elongate upon exposure to polarized light along the polarization direction.
(38,39)
However, the use of photoswitchable surfactants to tune the shape of BCP particles has never been reported. This is mainly attributed to the difficulty in designing the photoswitchable surfactants that exhibit considerable changes in their amphiphilicity by light irradiation.

Herein, we report the development of BCP particles that reversibly change their shape in response to light at a specific wavelength via the use of photoisomerizable surfactants. The surfactant molecules are carefully designed to contain a light-responsive moiety that exhibits significant changes in its amphiphilicity upon isomerization. We chose spiropyran (SP) as a photoswitchable group that reversibly isomerizes between the hydrophobic ring-closed SP and hydrophilic ring-opened merocyanine forms upon irradiation with visible or UV light, respectively.
(44,45)
In addition, an alkyl chain spacer bearing a terminal ionic group is incorporated into the surfactant to afford an appropriate hydrophilicâlipophilic balance (HLB), allowing its use as an effective surfactant for oil-in-water emulsions. This SP-based surfactant enables wavelength-selective tuning of the interfacial energy between the surfactant molecules and polystyrene-
b
-poly(4-vinylpyridine) (PS-
b
-P4VP) BCP chains. Irradiation with visible light induces the formation of the anisotropic particles (i.e., prolate or oblate ellipsoids), which transform into onion-like spherical particles upon irradiation with UV light (365 nm). Importantly, the shape and optical properties of the BCP particles are reversibly switched over multiple cycles upon repeated exposure to visible or UV light. Finally, these BCP particles are incorporated into a composite hydrogel film that exhibits reversible patterning capabilities with distinct color changes activated by specific wavelengths of light.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Scheme 1
shows the synthetic route used to prepare the photoresponsive surfactants, spiropyran-dodecyltrimethylammoium bromide (SP-DTAB), and the mechanism for the shape changes of the PS-
b
-P4VP particles using the SP-DTAB surfactants. The SP-DTAB molecule consists of three parts: (1) a photoresponsive SP group, (2) an alkyl chain spacer, and (3) an ionic terminal moiety. The SP group can isomerize between its hydrophobic ring-closed SP form (RC form) under visible light and the hydrophilic, ring-opened merocyanine form (RO form) under UV irradiation.
(44,45)
This wavelength-dependent isomerization of the SP-DTAB surfactant enables reversible changes in its interfacial activity between the PS and P4VP blocks in the BCP particles
(41)
and thereby allows for the shape transformation of BCP particles between spherical onion-like particles with a P4VP outermost layer and ellipsoidal particles with both PS and P4VP exposed to the surface of the particles (
Scheme 1
b). In addition, the dodecyl chain bearing a trimethylammonium bromide (DTAB) terminal group endows SP-DTAB with the appropriate HLB required to form stable chloroform-in-water emulsions. The SP-DTAB surfactant was synthesized from 2,3,3-trimethylindolenine (
Scheme 1
a) and characterized with
1
H nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy (
Figure S1
),
13
C NMR spectroscopy (
Figure S2
), Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy (
Figure S3
), and matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization-time-of-flight (MALDI-TOF) spectrometry (
Figure S4
). The photoisomerization behavior of SP-DTAB was monitored by using the UVâvis spectroscopy of the aqueous surfactant solution under UV or visible light irradiation obtained at different times (
Figures
1
and
S5
). As shown in
Figure
1
a, a distinct absorption peak at 501 nm under UV irradiation was attributed to the extended Ï-conjugation of the RO isomer.
(46â48)
In contrast, the peak at 501 nm disappeared under visible light due to the photoisomerization to the RC form of SP-DTAB (
Figure
1
b). Furthermore, the color of the surfactant solution changed from red to yellow. The slow CâO cleavage process required a much longer time (i.e., several hours) for the isomerization from the RC to RO form compared with the reverse isomerization from the RO to RC form.
(49)

Scheme 1. (a) Synthesis of the Spiropyran-DTAB (SP-DTAB) Surfactant. (b) Schematic Illustration of the Light-Responsive PS-
b
-P4VP Particles That Change Their Shape through Wavelength-Selective Photoisomerization of the SP-DTAB Surfactants

The BCP particles were prepared by emulsifying a chloroform solution of PS-
b
-P4VP (100 Î¼L, 5 mg mL
â1
) in an aqueous solution containing SP-DTAB (1 mL, 0.5 mg mL
â1
). The chloroform in the emulsion was evaporated over 1 h to produce BCP particles. Both the emulsification and solvent evaporation processes were carried out under UV (365 nm) or visible light irradiation to promote the isomerization of SP-DTAB to the RO or RC form, respectively.
Figure
2
aâf shows the transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of the symmetric PS
10k
-
b
-P4VP
10k
(subscripts indicate the number-average molecular weight (
M
n
) of each block) BCP particles prepared with SP-DTAB surfactants under either UV or visible light. Specifically, spherical BCP particles with a concentric lamellar morphology were obtained under UV irradiation. The outermost layer of these particles consisted of the P4VP chains (
Figure
2
aâc). In contrast, visible light led to the formation of prolate ellipsoidal particles containing axially stacked lamellar morphologies (
Figure
2
dâf). This morphological transition is attributed to the change in the interfacial properties of the BCPs toward the surrounding medium.
(19,50,51)
Particularly, the hydrophilic RO form of SP-DTAB induced by UV light preferentially interacts with the P4VP chains, yielding the outermost P4VP layer on the spherical BCP particles. In contrast, the relatively hydrophobic RC surfactant shows no preference and equally wets the PS and P4VP domains at the emulsion interface under visible light irradiation.

div.p:
Figure 2. (aâf) TEM and SEM (low and high magnifications) images of the PS
10k
-
b
-P4VP
10k
particles prepared with (aâc) the RO form surfactant under irradiation with UV light and (dâf) the RC form surfactant under irradiation with visible light. (g) Photoluminescence (PL) spectra of an aqueous suspension (2 mg mL
â1
) of the spherical (orange) and ellipsoidal (blue) PS
10k
-
b
-P4VP
10k
particles. The insets are the fluorescence optical images obtained for each particle suspension under excitation at 420 nm using a 495 nm light filter.

div.div:
In our system, the SP-DTAB surfactant exhibits a luminescence peak at 615 nm when excited using 420 nm light,
(52)
allowing for the color visualization of each particle shape. To correlate the particle shape to the optical signal, the emission properties of the BCP particles were explored by measuring the photoluminescence (PL) of the BCP particle solutions prepared using the RO form or the RC form of the SP-DTAB surfactant. The BCP particles were extensively washed with deionized water (i.e., about 10 times) to completely remove any residual surfactants in water before acquiring the PL spectra. Moreover, the PL properties can be accurately monitored without disturbing the isomeric population of the surfactant as there is no photoconversion between the RO and RC form upon excitation at 420 nm.
(1,53)
Figure
2
g shows that the aqueous suspension of the spherical particles stabilized by the RO surfactant exhibits a strong fluorescence emission peak at 615 nm due to the conjugated structure of merocyanine, causing the solution to emit an orange color. In contrast, the ellipsoidal particle suspension was nearly colorless with a 72.5% reduction in its fluorescence due to the isomerization of SP into the RC form. This result was consistent with the PL spectra of the SP-DTAB solution upon isomerization (
Figure S6
).

To develop a comprehensive understanding of the photodriven change of the particle shape, we quantitatively analyzed the interfacial selectivity of SP-DTAB for the PS or P4VP phases. The overall structure and internal morphology of BCP particles are governed by the orientation of the first few BCP layers at the beginning of the nucleation process (i.e., parallel orientation for onion-like spheres and perpendicular orientation for striped ellipsoids,
Scheme S1
),
(54â57)
which is determined by the interactions between the surfactants and BCP chains at the chloroform/water interface.
(19,50,51)
Since the amphiphilicity of the SP-DTAB surfactant shifts upon structural isomerization, the difference in the interfacial tensions (i.e., Î³
PS/surr
â Î³
P4VP/surr
) will significantly vary to induce the orientational change of the BCP chains relative to the particle surface.
(19,27,29)
To investigate the influence of the changes of the SP-DTAB between the RO and RC forms on the Î³
PS/surr
and Î³
P4VP/surr
, a pendant drop tensiometer was used to measure the interfacial tension (Î³) between the chloroform solution of the polymers (PS or P4VP, 1 or 5 wt %) and an aqueous RO or RC surfactant solution (0.5 and 0.75 mg/mL). The results are shown in
Tables
1
and
S1 and Figure S7
. The presence of either the RO or RC form of SP-DTAB induced a significant Î³ reduction for both PS and P4VP, indicating a strong adsorption of SP-DTAB along the chloroform/water interface. For the 5 wt % PS chloroform droplet, the Î³ value with the RO surfactant solution was 12.60 mN m
â1
, which was larger than that with the RC surfactant solution (8.93 mN m
â1
), indicating that the hydrophobic PS polymers interact preferably with RC surfactant over the RO surfactant. For the 5 wt % P4VP chloroform droplet, significantly lower Î³ values of â¼5 mN m
â1
were observed for both the RO and RC forms of SP-DTAB due to the hydrophilic nature of P4VP. Thus, the Î³
PS/surr
â Î³
P4VP/surr
value was much larger for the RO surfactant (7.59 mN m
â1
) than for the RC surfactant (3.52 mN m
â1
). A similar trend was consistently observed for the case with a higher concentration of SP-DTAB (i.e., 7.13 and 2.98 mN m
â1
at 0.75 mg mL
â1
of the RO and RC surfactants, respectively;
Table S1
). A distinct difference of the Î³ values between the RO and RC surfactants generates a sufficient driving force to overcome the energy barrier for the orientation change of the BCPs. PS and P4VP blocks show a comparable interaction with the aqueous medium of the RC surfactants under visible light, which promotes the formation of ellipsoidal particles with a perpendicularly stacked lamellar morphology. In contrast, the RO surfactants favorably interact with P4VP over PS domains, producing onion-shaped particles with a P4VP-outermost layer. We performed a control experiment to support that the change in Î³ of the RO and RC surfactants is sufficient to induce the shape change of the PS-
b
-P4VP BCP particles. The onion PS-
b
-P4VP particles were produced using the 16-hydroxy-cetyltriethylammonium bromide (CTEAB-OH) surfactant while the prolate PS-
b
-P4VP particles were generated by a mixture of cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) and complementary CTEABâOH surfactants that preferably interact with PS and P4VP, respectively (
Table S2 and Figure S8
). These results were consistent with the previous reports.
(19)
Again, the Î³ values were measured for the emulsion conditions with two different structured particles. For the P4VP-preferred surfactant, Î³
PS/surr
â Î³
P4VP/surr
was measured to be 7.19 mN m
â1
, whereas the Î³
PS/surr
â Î³
P4VP/surr
value for the emulsion producing the prolate particles was much smaller, 3.18 mN m
â1
. These observations were consistent with the Î³ change from the RO and RC surfactants.

The achievement of a reversible response to an external stimulus is one of the most important attributes for the potential applications of dynamic shape-switchable particles. To demonstrate this important capability, the reversibility of the shape transformations of the BCP particles is examined upon repeated UV and visible light irradiations (
Figures
3
and
S9
). The solvent vapor annealing using chloroform, a good solvent for both PS and P4VP, was applied to provide sufficient chain mobility for the structural reorganization within the BCP particles.
(17,18)
An aqueous suspension of the BCP particles was irradiated under a chloroform atmosphere for 6 h, followed by evaporation of the residual chloroform for 1 h to reach their thermodynamically stable structure. Upon visible light irradiation, the onion-like spherical BCP particles transformed into ellipsoids, consistent with the results shown in
Figure
2
. Subsequent exposure with UV light reversed the particle shape and internal morphology back to the spherical particles, as shown in
Figure
3
a. Further light-responsive shape transformations of the BCP particles were successfully carried out over 10 cycles (
Figures
3
and
S10
). The emission color of the particle suspension switched between orange and nearly colorless depending on the particle shape. This emission change was monitored by measuring the change in the PL intensity of the particle suspension (
Figure S11
). During the subsequent irradiation of UV and visible light, the absorbance spectra of the SP-DTAB surfactant were monitored. The normalized absorbance intensity profile of the SP-DTAB surfactant at 501 nm was plotted as a function of the number of cycles, as shown in
Figure
3
b. A significant decrease in the absorbance at 501 nm was observed when the particles were transformed from spheres to ellipsoids. This change was reproducible over 10 successive cycles. However, hydrolysis of the SP moiety in water causes some photofatigue (i.e., deactivation of 28% of the surfactant molecules) through the repeated isomerization processes.
(58,59)
Nevertheless, a strong correlation between the photoisomerization of SP-DTAB and the shape and color changes of the BCP particles was observed, demonstrating a robust and reversible light-responsive particle platform.

div.p:
Figure 3. (a) TEM images and the corresponding fluorescence optical images (insets) of the PS
10k
-
b
-P4VP
10k
particles showing the reversible shape and color changes under subsequent irradiation with UV and visible light. The scale bars represent 100 nm. (b) The normalized absorbance intensity profile at 501 nm for the SP-DTAB surfactant in water (0.125 mg mL
â1
) as a function of the number of cycles.

div.div:
To demonstrate the versatility of SP-DTAB, the light-responsive behaviors of particles containing different
M
n
and volume fractions were investigated. First, PS
19k
-
b
-P4VP
22k
, which has a similar volume fraction but higher
M
n
than PS
10k
-
b
-P4VP
10k
, was emulsified with SP-DTAB. Similar to the results observed for PS
10k
-
b
-P4VP
10k
, onion-like spherical particles were formed under UV irradiation, whereas visible light yielded ellipsoidal particles (
Figure
4
a). The higher
M
n
of PS
19k
-
b
-P4VP
22k
resulted in a larger domain size (38.1 nm) compared with that of the PS
10k
-
b
-P4VP
10k
particles (24.6 nm). In another set of experiments, cylinder-forming PS
27k
-
b
-P4VP
7k
with SP-DTAB exhibited spherical particles with coiled P4VP cylinders and a P4VP-outermost layer under the UV irradiation. In contrast, irradiation with visible light yielded oblate particles with a hexagonally packed internal structure, as shown in the side-view SEM (top) and TEM (bottom) images in
Figure
4
b. In addition, the reversible shape transformation between the spheres and ellipsoids (both prolates and oblates) was demonstrated through sequential UVâvisible light irradiations.

div.p:
Figure 4. TEM and side-view SEM images of the photoswitchable BCP particles with different
M
n
or volume fractions: (a) PS
19k
-
b
-P4VP
22k
(sphere and prolate) and (b) PS
27k
-
b
-P4VP
7k
(sphere and oblate). The percentage of frequency of each particle morphology is depicted in the bar charts with different colors: sphere (blue), prolate and oblate ellipsoids (red), and intermediate (yellow). Scale bars are 100 nm.

div.div:
As the BCP particles exhibit a unique optical signal depending on their shape, the particles can behave as independent color pixels that display the changes of the local light irradiation with submicrometer resolution. To demonstrate the reversible color display using our BCP particles, we fabricated a free-standing hydrogel film by incorporating the oblate PS
27k
-
b
-P4VP
7k
particles into a hydrogel matrix (
Figure
5
a,b). UV-initiated polymerization of a gel solution composed of poly(ethylene glycol) diacrylate, sodium acrylate, and BCP particles was utilized to fabricate a composite hydrogel film.
(15,60)
When the hydrogel film was selectively exposed to UV light through the letter-patterned photomask in the chloroform atmosphere, the dark pink-colored letters appeared (
Figure
5
c). The more intense fluorescence of the patterned letters was observed under excitation at 420 nm (
Figure
5
d). This local color change was further supported by the cross-sectional SEM images of the freeze-dried hydrogel film, where only the particles in the UV-exposed area transformed from oblates to spheres driven by the photoisomerization of SP-DTAB (
Figure
5
e,f). Finally, the reversible patterning capability of the hydrogel film was demonstrated through sequential irradiation of UV and visible light using different photomasks (i.e., âKAISTâ, âKâ, âAâ, âIâ, âSâ, or âTâ letter-patterned photomasks). Each letter was selectively imprinted on and removed from the composite hydrogel film upon local light irradiation (UV or visible light), enabled by the reversible shape and color change of the BCP particles (
Figure
5
g).

div.p:
Figure 5. BCP particle-containing composite hydrogel film demonstrating reversible patterning features. (a) A schematic representation of the preparation of the reversibly patternable hydrogel film. (b) Photograph of the composite hydrogel film containing oblate PS
27k
-
b
-P4VP
7k
particles. (c, d) Photographs of the patterned hydrogel film after UV irradiation on a lettered photomask (c) taken under visible light and (d) upon excitation at 420 nm. (e, f) SEM images of (e) the visible light-exposed area and (f) the UV light-exposed area on the freeze-dried hydrogel film. (g) Demonstration of letter writing/erasing by sequential irradiations of UV and visible light.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div: In this work, we reported BCP particles that reversibly change shape and color in response to light of a specific wavelength. This was achieved by developing photoswitchable SP-DTAB surfactants that exhibit a significant change in their amphiphilicity and interfacial activity upon photoisomerization. Under UV irradiation, the SP group converted to the hydrophilic RO form, leading to a strong preference for the P4VP domain. In contrast, visible light promoted a ring-closing process to yield a neutral preference for both the P4VP and PS domains. These light-responsive properties of the SP-DTAB surfactants enabled the formation of differently structured particles of orange color-emitting spheres under UV light and colorless ellipsoids under visible light, respectively. Sequential irradiations with UV and visible light allowed the reversible change in particle shape and color over multiple cycles. Moreover, we demonstrated the composite film with micrometer-resolution photoactive display capabilities, highlighting the potential of these photoswitchable particles.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

= 1.08).

12-(3â²,3â²-Dimethyl-6-nitrospiro[chromene-2,2â²-indolin]-1â²-yl)-
N
,
N
,
N
-trimethyldodecan-1-aminium bromide (SP-DTAB) was synthesized by modifying the method reported in the literature.
(61)
2,3,3-Trimethylindolenine (2 g, 12.6 mmol) and 1,12-dibromodoedecane (4.55 g, 13.86 mmol) were added into a two-neck flask with 20 mL of acetonitrile. The reaction mixture was refluxed under a N
2
atmosphere for 24 h. After cooling to room temperature, the remaining solvent was distilled under reduced pressure. An aqueous NaOH solution (1 M, 200 mL) was then added to the residue, and the mixture was stirred for 3 h at room temperature. This suspension was extracted using dichloromethane, and the organic phase was concentrated by a rotary evaporator. A mixture of the product and 2-hydroxy-5-nitrobenzaldehyde (2.18 g, 13.0 mmol) in ethanol (20 mL) was heated for 24 h under reflux and a N
2
atmosphere. After cooling to 4 Â°C, the precipitates were formed, and subsequent washing with cold ethanol gave a greenish powder. Next, an excess amount of trimethylamine in ethyl acetate (100 mL) was added and stirred for 5 days at room temperature under an Ar atmosphere. The solvent was distilled under reduced pressure, and residual byproducts were filtered by cold methanol. Finally, SP-DTAB was obtained by precipitating it in cold hexane (yield: 800 mg, 9.91%).

div.h3:
4.3. Preparation of Reversible Shape-Changing PS-
b
-P4VP BCP Particles
div.div:
To fully isomerize SP-DTAB to the RO form or RC form, UV or visible light was irradiated for 6 h on an aqueous solution of SP-DTAB (0.5 mg mL
â1
), respectively. The 365 nm UV lamp (20 W) and green colored LED lamp (24 W) were used with a distance between the lamp and the solution of 30 cm. The particles were produced from the chloroform-in-water emulsions, which were prepared by emulsifying a chloroform solution of PS
10k
-
b
-P4VP
10k
or PS
19k
-
b
-P4VP
22k
(100 Î¼L, 5 mg mL
â1
) or PS
27k
-
b
-P4VP
7k
(50 Î¼L, 40 mg mL
â1
) into an RO or RC form surfactant aqueous solution (1 mL, 0.5 mg mL
â1
). After evaporation of chloroform under reduced pressure for 1 h, BCP particles were obtained. To achieve a reversible shape transition of the BCP particles, solvent vapor annealing was performed. First, a small vial of the spherical (or ellipsoidal) particle suspension in the RO form (or RC form) surfactant solution (1 mL) was placed in a large vial containing 1 mL of chloroform. The chloroform vapor was allowed to dissolve into the particle suspension under visible light (or UV) irradiation during stirring for 6 h. Once the particles were swollen by chloroform vapor, evaporation of absorbed chloroform resulted in a shape transition of the BCP particles between spheres and ellipsoids.

div.h3: 4.4. Preparation of Patternable Composite Hydrogel Film
div.div:
A gel solution was prepared by dissolving poly(ethylene glycol) diacrylate (
M
n
= 575 g mol
â1
, 1.8 g), sodium acrylate (0.2 g), 2-hydroxy-2-methylpropiophenone (20 mg), SP-DTAB (2.0 mg), and oblate PS
27k
-
b
-P4VP
7k
particles formed by SP-DTAB (10.0 mg) in 1.0 mL of DI water. After injecting the gel solution between two slide glasses, UV light (254 nm, 200 Î¼W cm
â2
) was irradiated for 10 min to solidify the gel solution. After rinsing with DI water to wash the unreacted residues, a composite hydrogel film with 65 mm Ã 25 mm Ã 1 mm size was produced. A letter-patterned hydrogel film was obtained by exposure of UV light to the hydrogel film covered with letter-patterned photomasks while chloroform vapor annealing was applied.

Synthesized SP-DTAB was characterized by NMR (Bruker AMX 500), FT-IR (Nicolet iS50), and MALDI-TOF spectrometry (Bruker autoflex III). UVâvis absorption spectra of the surfactant solutions were obtained by a UV-1800 spectrophotometer (Shimadzu Scientific Instruments). PL spectra of BCP particles were obtained by an FL-1057 fluorescence spectrophotometer (HORIBA). The pendant drop images were taken with a CCD camera (WAT-902H Ultimate, Watec) and analyzed by the Matlab program. SEM (Magellan400) and TEM (Tecnai F20) were used for observing the overall shape and internal morphologies of the BCP particles. To prepare SEM and TEM samples, the BCP particle suspensions were drop-casted onto the silicon wafer and the TEM grids were coated with 20 nm-thick carbon film. To get clear images of the internal structure of the BCP particles by TEM, P4VP domains were selectively stained with iodine vapor.

Polymer nanoparticles of 40-400 nm diam. with spiropyran-merocyanine dyes incorporated into their hydrophobic cavities have been prepd.; in contrast to their virtually nonfluorescent character in most environments, the merocyanine forms of the encapsulated dyes are highly fluorescent. Spiro-mero photoisomerization is reversible, allowing the fluorescence to be switched "on" and "off" by alternating UV and visible light. Immobilizing the dye inside hydrophobic pockets of nanoparticles also improves its photostability, rendering it more resistant than the same dyes in soln. to fatigue effects arising from photochem. switching. The photophys. characteristics of the encapsulated fluorophores differ dramatically from those of the same species in soln., making nanoparticle-protected hydrophobic fluorophores attractive materials for potential applications such as optical data storage and switching and biol. fluorescent labeling. To evaluate the potential for biol. tagging, these optically addressable nanoparticles have been delivered into living cells and imaged with a liq. nitrogen-cooled CCD.

Here, we report a novel polymeric nanoparticle prepd. by the self-assembly of amphiphilic copolymers contg. a fluorescent naphthalimide (NAPH) and a photochromic spiropyran (SP), which possesses reversibly photoswitchable dual-color fluorescence and controlled release properties. The amphiphilic copolymers were synthesized by incorporating NAPH and SP into Me ether poly(ethylene glycol)-poly(Î²-amino esters) (MPEG-PAE) via quaternization. The nanoparticles would change between yellow and purple reversibly upon UV and visible light irradn. because of the photoisomerization between SP and merocyanine (MC). The corresponding fluorescence would be switched between green and orange-red reversibly upon blue light excitation through the fluorescence resonance energy transfer from the excited NAPH to the photoisomerized MC. Meanwhile, the prepd. spherical nanoparticles could be swollen under UV irradn. as the hydrophobic SP isomerized to hydrophilic MC; the nanoparticles could also be swollen under acidic conditions because of the protonation of the amino groups of PAE. Upon UV light irradn. and acidic stimulation, the cargoes, hydrophobic Coumarin 102, encapsulated in the nanoparticles would be released. The prepd. nanoparticles, which exhibit not only excellent reversible dual-color fluorescence properties but also prominent controlled release performance, will open up new possibilities for the combined application of fluorescence imaging and controlled release.

Suppression of the coffee-ring effect by shape-dependent capillary interactions
Yunker, Peter J.; Still, Tim; Lohr, Matthew A.; Yodh, A. G.
Nature (London, United Kingdom)

When a drop of liq. dries on a solid surface, its suspended particulate matter is deposited in ring-like fashion. This phenomenon, known as the coffee-ring effect, is familiar to anyone who has obsd. a drop of coffee dry. During the drying process, drop edges become pinned to the substrate, and capillary flow outward from the center of the drop brings suspended particles to the edge as evapn. proceeds. After evapn., suspended particles are left highly concd. along the original drop edge. The coffee-ring effect is manifested in systems with diverse constituents, ranging from large colloids to nanoparticles and individual mols. In fact-despite the many practical applications for uniform coatings in printing, biol. and complex assembly-the ubiquitous nature of the effect has made it difficult to avoid. Here we show exptl. that the shape of the suspended particles is important and can be used to eliminate the coffee-ring effect: ellipsoidal particles are deposited uniformly during evapn. The anisotropic shape of the particles significantly deforms interfaces, producing strong interparticle capillary interactions. Thus, after the ellipsoids are carried to the air-water interface by the same outward flow that causes the coffee-ring effect for spheres, strong long-ranged interparticle attractions between ellipsoids lead to the formation of loosely packed or arrested structures on the air-water interface. These structures prevent the suspended particles from reaching the drop edge and ensure uniform deposition. Interestingly, under appropriate conditions, suspensions of spheres mixed with a small no. of ellipsoids also produce uniform deposition. Thus, particle shape provides a convenient parameter to control the deposition of particles, without modification of particle or solvent chem.

We exptl. and theor. investigate the shapes of contact lines on the surfaces of micrometer-sized polystyrene ellipsoids at the water-air interface. By combining interferometry and optical trapping, we directly observe quadrupolar symmetry of the interface deformations around such particles. We then develop numerical solns. of the partial wetting problem for ellipsoids, and use these solns. to deduce the shapes of the corresponding contact lines and the values of the contact angles, Î¸c(k), as a function of the ellipsoid aspect ratio k. Surprisingly, Î¸c is found to decrease for increasing k suggesting that ellipsoid microscopic surface properties depend on ellipsoid aspect ratio.

Cracks in a colloidal film formed by evapn. induced drying can be controlled by changing drying conditions. We show, for the first time that the crack morphologies in colloidal films are dependent on shape of constituting particles apart from the microstructure and particle assembly. In order to investigate the particle shape effect on crack patterns, monodispered spherical and ellipsoidal particles are used in sessile drop expts. On observing the dried sessile drop we found cracks along the radial direction for spherical particle dispersions and circular crack patterns for ellipsoidal particle dispersions. The change in crack pattern is a result of self assembly of shape anisotropic particles and their ordering. The ordering of particles dictate the crack direction and the cracks follow the path of least resistance to release the excess stress stored in the particle film. Ellipsoids having different aspect ratio (â¼3 to 7) are used and circular crack patterns are repeatedly obsd. in all expts.

Block copolymers (BCPs) confined in evaporative emulsions can assemble into ellipsoidal particles when solvent evapn. is faster than polymer diffusion within the droplet. Here, we report the synthesis of monodisperse, ellipsoidal polystyrene-block-1,4-polybutadiene (PS-b-PB) BCP particles with tunable aspect ratios (ARs) ranging from 1.0 to 2.2 and particle sizes ranging from 0.1 to 5 Î¼m by membrane emulsification and subsequent solvent evapn. The ratio of the propagation distance (lp) of ordered BCP domains perpendicular to the particle surface to the particle size (rBCP), or lp/rBCP, was found to be a crit. parameter dictating the particle shape, where lp/rBCP > 1 yielded ellipsoids. We show that the AR of colloidal BCP ellipsoids can be precisely controlled by varying particle size (i.e., membrane pore size) and BCP mol. wt., as predicted by theor. calcns. of the free energy of particle elongation including three terms: (1) the interfacial energy between the two blocks of the BCP, (2) the entropic penalty assocd. with stretching of the BCP chains upon elongation of the particles, and (3) the surface energy between the BCP particles and the surrounding medium. Finally, using the resulting AR-controlled and highly monodisperse colloidal ellipsoids, we systematically investigated the effects of AR on the homogeneity of colloidal coatings obtained by drop-casting the ellipsoids into films.

Particle engineering for biomedical applications has unfolded the roles of attributes such as size, surface chem., and shape for modulating particle interactions with cells. Recently, dynamic manipulation of such key properties has gained attention in view of the need to precisely control particle interaction with cells. With increasing recognition of the pivotal role of particle shape in detg. their biomedical applications, the authors report on polymeric particles that are able to switch their shape in real time in a stimulus-responsive manner. The shape-switching behavior was driven by a subtle balance between polymer viscosity and interfacial tension. The balance between the 2 forces was modulated by application of an external stimulus chosen from temp., pH, or chem. additives. The dynamics of shape switch was precisely controlled over minutes to days under physiol. conditions. Shape-switching particles exhibited unique interactions with cells. Elliptical disk-shaped particles that are not phagocytosed by macrophages were made to internalize through shape switch, demonstrating the ability of shape-switchable particles in modulating interaction with cells.

A review. Stimuli-responsive polymer materials are powerful tools in drug delivery and tissue engineering. Because of the large variations in physiol. conditions between normal microenvironments and diseased sites, polymer materials with single responsiveness may not achieve the desired goals in a complex physiol. microenvironment. Instead, polymer materials responsive to multiple phys. or chem. stimuli are highly desired for biomedical applications (e.g., drug delivery). In this , we highlight recent studies in multi-stimuli-responsive materials with a specific emphasis on polymer particles, films, and hydrogels. The synthetic strategies employed to produce these responsive materials are described. Applications in drug delivery are highlighted, followed by a discussion of the current research focus and future trends.

Structured light enables biomimetic swimming and versatile locomotion of photoresponsive soft microrobots
Palagi, Stefano; Mark, Andrew G.; Reigh, Shang Yik; Melde, Kai; Qiu, Tian; Zeng, Hao; Parmeggiani, Camilla; Martella, Daniele; Sanchez-Castillo, Alberto; Kapernaum, Nadia; Giesselmann, Frank; Wiersma, Diederik S.; Lauga, Eric; Fischer, Peer

Microorganisms move in challenging environments by periodic changes in body shape. In contrast, current artificial microrobots cannot actively deform, exhibiting at best passive bending under external fields. Here, by taking advantage of the wireless, scalable and spatiotemporally selective capabilities that light allows, we show that soft microrobots consisting of photoactive liq.-crystal elastomers can be driven by structured monochromatic light to perform sophisticated biomimetic motions. We realize continuum yet selectively addressable artificial microswimmers that generate travelling-wave motions to self-propel without external forces or torques, as well as microrobots capable of versatile locomotion behaviors on demand. Both theor. predictions and exptl. results confirm that multiple gaits, mimicking either symplectic or antiplectic metachrony of ciliate protozoa, can be achieved with single microswimmers. The principle of using structured light can be extended to other applications that require microscale actuation with sophisticated spatiotemporal coordination for advanced microrobotic technologies.

Acrylic polymers contg. cinnamic groups can be deformed and fixed into pre-detd. shapes such as (but not exclusively) elongated films and tubes, arches or spirals-by UV light illumination. The polymers are based on Bu acrylate (BA), hydroxyethyl methacrylate (HEMA) and ethylene glycol-1-acrylate-2-cinnamic acid (HEA-CA) with poly(propylene glycol)dimethacrylate as crosslinker. In the second polymer (IPN polymer), the permanent network is formed from BA with poly(propylene glycol)dimethacrylate as crosslinker and about 20% star-poly(ethylene glycol) with cinnamylideneacetic acid (CAA) terminal groups. These shapes are stable for long time periods, even when heated to 50Â°, and they can recover their original shape at ambient temps. when exposed to UV light of a different wavelength. The ability of polymers to form different pre-detd. temporary shapes and subsequently recover their original shape at ambient temps. by remote light activation could lead to a variety of potential medical and other applications.

A review. Stimuli-responsive polymers are the subject of intense research because they are able to show responses to various environmental changes. Among those stimuli, light has attracted much attention since it can be localized in time and space and it can also be triggered from outside of the system. In this paper, we review light-responsive block copolymers (LRBCs) that combine characteristic features of block copolymers, e.g., self-assembly behavior, and light-responsive systems. The different photo-responsive moieties that have been incorporated so far in block copolymers as well as the proposed applications are discussed.

A visible light-induced switching of surface chem. patterns is described based on hybrid gels of PNIPAM contg. iron oxide nanoparticles. Due to the superparamagnetic properties of these NPs, similar composites undergo reversible swelling changes when heated using an ac magnetic field. Here, instead, relying on their strong light absorbance to generate heat and reversible deswelling of gel layers was achieved using a modest intensity light source, i.e., a mercury lamp for fluorescence microscopy. Furthermore, the use of localized illumination allowed selective switching of individual elements within a dynamic chem. pattern.

The possibility of wavelength-selective cleavage of seven photolabile caging groups from different families has been studied. Amine-, thiol-, and carboxylic-terminated organosilanes were caged with o-nitrobenzyl (NVOC, NPPOC), benzoin (BNZ), (coumarin-4-yl)methyl (DEACM), 7-nitroindoline (DNI, BNI), and p-hydroxyphenacyl (pHP) derivs. Caged surfaces modified with the different chromophores were prepd., and their photosensitivity at selected wavelengths was quantified. Different pairs, trios, and quartets of chromophore combinations with wavelength-selective photoresponse were identified. Our results show, for the first time, the possibility of generating surfaces with up to four different and independently addressable functional levels. In addn., this manuscript presents the first systematic comparison of the photolytic properties of different photolabile groups under different irradn. conditions.

The photocleavable monomers, bis(2-(4'-(dimethylamino)-4-nitro-[1,1'-biphenyl]-3-yl)propyl) hexane-1,6-diyldicarbamate [(NH-ANBP)2] and 2-(4'-(2-hydroxyethoxy)-4-nitro-[1,1'-biphenyl]-3-yl)propan-1-ol [PMNB(OH)2] allow sequential photoactivation of independent crosslinking and depolymn. steps in a dual polyurethane (PU) mixt. using single photon exposure at 520 and 365 nm, or two-photon exposure at 820 and 780 nm. Using masked irradn. or scanning lasers, 2D and 3D control of the reaction steps can be achieved. This approach is not restricted to urethane prepolymer mixts. and can be applied to other types of reactive monomers and polymeric backbones. Taking into account that these chromophores are typically applied in expts. with living cells, we envision that this approach will not only be attractive for microfabrication, but also be applicable to biomaterials research.

A robust strategy is developed for prepg. light-responsive block copolymer (BCP) particles in which shape and color can be actively controlled with high spatial and temporal resoln. The key to achieving light-responsive shape transitions of BCP particles is the design and synthesis of surfactants contg. light-active groups (i.e., nitrobenzyl esters and coumarin esters) that modulate the amphiphilicity and interfacial activity of the surfactants in response to light of a specific wavelength. These light-induced changes in surfactant structure modify the surface and wetting properties of BCP particles, affording both shape and morphol. transitions of the particles, for example from spheres with an onion-like inner morphol. to prolate or oblate ellipsoids with axially stacked nanostructures. In particular, wavelength-selective shape transformation of the BCP particles can be achieved with a mixt. of two light-active surfactants that respond to different wavelengths of light (i.e., 254 and 420 nm). Through the use of light-emitting, photoresponsive surfactants, light-induced changes in both color and shape are further demonstrated. Finally, to demonstrate the potential of the light-triggered shape control of BCP particles in patterning features with microscale resoln., the shape-switchable BCP particles are successfully integrated into a patterned, free-standing hydrogel film, which can be used as a portable, high-resoln. display.

In this work, azobenzene-contg. colloidal spheres were fabricated and used to construct photoresponsive monolayers. The colloidal spheres were prepd. from an amphiphilic azobenzene-contg. random copolymer through hydrophobic aggregation of the polymer chains, which was induced by adding the selective solvent (H2O) into a THF soln. of the polymer. The size and size distribution of the spheres depended on the initial concn. of the azo polymer in THF and the H2O/THF ratio. Adjusting those factors and optimizing other prepn. conditions, uniform colloidal spheres could be obtained. Monolayers composed of hexagonally close-packed colloidal spheres were prepd. by the capillary-force-driven method. The colloidal monolayers showed obvious dichroism after laser irradn. due to the photoinduced azo-chromophore orientation occurred in the spheres. The orientation order parameter was related to the irradn. time and estd. to be 0.09 at the photostationary state. The colloidal spheres and their monolayers can potentially be used as building blocks or media for reversible optical data storage, photoswitching, sensors, and other photodriven devices.

Control of the shape, size, internal structure, and uniformity of block copolymer (BCP) particles is crucial for detg. their utility and functionality in practical applications. Here, we demonstrate a particle restructuring by solvent engineering (PRSE) strategy that combines membrane emulsification and solvent annealing processes to produce monodisperse BCP particles with controlled size, shape, and internal structure. A major advantage of the PRSE approach is the general applicability to different families of functional BCPs, including polystyrene-block-poly(1,4-butadiene) (PS-b-PB), polystyrene-block-poly(dimethylsiloxane) (PS-b-PDMS), and polystyrene-block-poly(4-vinylpyridine) (PS-b-P4VP). PRSE starts with the prodn. of monodisperse BCP spheres in a wide range of particle sizes (from hundreds of nanometers to several tens of microns) using membrane emulsification, followed by successful transformation to shape-anisotropic BCP particles by solvent annealing under neutral wetting conditions. Particle size monodispersity was maintained during the PRSE process with shape transformations from sphere to ellipsoids (i.e., oblate and prolate). The approach was effective in controlling the aspect ratio (AR) of both prolate and oblate ellipsoids over wide ranges. These ARs were well-supported by free energy calcns. based on a theor. model describing particle elongation. Further investigation of the shape-transformation kinetics during the PRSE process revealed that the morphol. transformation was driven by reorientation of BCP microdomains, with kinetics being strongly assocd. with the overall mol. wt. of the BCP as well as the annealing time.

Herein, we report a simple and robust strategy for prepg. dual-responsive shape-switchable block copolymer (BCP) particles, which respond to subtle temp. and pH changes near physiol. conditions (i.e., human body temp. and neutral pH). The shape transition of polystyrene-b-poly(4-vinylpyridine) BCP particles between lens and football shapes occurs in very narrow temp. and pH ranges: no temp.-based transition for pH 6.0, 40-50Â°C transition for pH 6.5, and 25-35Â°C for pH 7.0. To achieve these shape transitions, temp./pH-responsive polymer surfactants of poly(N-(2-(diethylamino)ethyl)acrylamide-r-N-isopropylacrylamide) are designed to induce dramatic changes in relative soly. and their location in response to temp. and pH changes near physiol. conditions. In addn., the BCP particles exhibit reversible shape-transforming behavior according to orthogonal temp. and pH changes. Colorimetric measurements of temp. and pH changes are enabled by shape-transforming properties combined with selective positioning of dyes, suggesting promising potential for these particles in clin. and biomedical applications.

A reversible transformation of overall shape and internal structure as well as surface compn. of nanostructured block copolymer particles is demonstrated by solvent-adsorption annealing. Polystyrene-b-poly-(4-vinylpyridine) (PS-b-P4VP) pupa-like particles with PS and P4VP lamellar domains alternatively stacked can be obtained by self-assembly of the block copolymer under 3D soft confinement. Chloroform, a good solvent for both blocks, is selected to swell and anneal the pupa-like particles suspended in aq. media. Reversible transformation between pupa-like and onion-like structures of the particles can be readily tuned by simply adjusting the particle/aq. soln. interfacial property. Interestingly, poly(vinyl alc.) (PVA) concn. in the aq. media plays a crit. role in detg. the particle morphol. High level of PVA concn. is favorable for pupa-like morphol., while extremely low concn. of PVA is favorable for the formation of onion-like particles. Moreover, the stimuli-response behavior of the particles can be highly suppressed through selective growth of Au nanoparticles within the P4VP domains. This strategy provides a new concept for the reversible transformation of nanostructured polymer particles, which will find potential applications in the field of sensing, detection, optical devices, drug delivery, and smart materials fabrication.

Based on studies combining expts. and simulations, internally ordered colloidal particles that are able to undergo morphol. transformations both in shape and internal structure are presented. The particles are prepd. by emulsion solvent evapn.-induced 3D soft confined assembly of di-block copolymer polystyrene-block-poly(4-vinylpyridine) (PS-b-P4VP). Control over the solvent selectivity leads to a dramatic change in shape and internal structure for particles. Pupa-like particles of lamellar morphol. are obtained when using a non-selective solvent, while patchy particles possessing a plum pudding structure formed when the solvent is selective for PS-block. More interestingly, 3D soft confined annealing drives order-order morphol. transformation of the particles. The morphol. of reshaped particles can be well controlled by varying the solvent selectivity, annealing time, and interfacial interaction. The exptl. results can be explained based on simulations. This study can offer considerable scope for the design of new stimuli-responsive colloidal particles for potential applications in photonic crystal, drug delivery and release, sensor and smart coating, etc.

A review. Responsive colloidal polymer particles with well-defined shapes and ordered internal mesostructures are attracting increasing attention because of their potential applications in sensors, catalysis, nano-drug carriers, color pigments, and others. Recently, 3D confined assembly of block copolymers in emulsion droplets has emerged as a promising method for fabrication of colloidal polymer particles with controllable shapes and internal structures. In this paper, the recent advances in engineering anisotropically shaped and internally ordered colloidal polymer particles are summarized, followed by highlighting their stimuli-responsiveness and emerging applications. In the last section, the current challenges and future opportunities in this fast growing research field are discussed.

Precise control over the spatial arrangement of inorg. nanoparticles on a large scale is desirable for the design of functional nanomaterials, sensing, and optical/electronic devices. Although great progress has been recently made in controlling the organization of nanoparticles, there still remains a grand challenge to arrange nanoparticles into highly-ordered arrays over multiple length scales. Here, we report the directed arrangement of inorg. nanoparticles into arrayed structures with long-range order, up to tens of microns, by using hexagonally-packed cylindrical patterns of block copolymer nanosheets self-assembled within collapsed emulsion droplets as scaffolds. This technique can be used to generate nanoparticle arrays with various nanoparticle arrangements, including hexagonal honeycomb structures, periodic nanoring structures, and their combinations. This finding provides an effective route to fabricate diverse nanoparticle arrayed structures for the design of functional materials and devices.

Compared to synthesizing a new block copolymer, blending of two types of block copolymers or a block copolymer and a homopolymer is a simple yet effective approach to create new self-assembled nanostructures. Here, we apply Monte Carlo (MC) simulations to mimic the co-assembly of AB/BC diblock copolymer blends within a three-dimensional (3D) soft confined space, which corresponds to the co-assembly confined in an emulsion droplet in expt. The confined co-assemblies of four types of block copolymer blends at different block ratios, i.e., A8B8/B8C8, A6B10/B10C6, A12B4/B4C12 and A12B4/B10C6, are investigated by MC simulations. The simulation results reveal that the ratio of different types of blocks and the polymer-solvent interactions between the different blocks and the solvent det. the final self-assembled nanostructures. By tailoring these two controlling parameters, we not only reproduced some classic nanostructures, i.e., pupa-, onion-, and bud-like particles, but also predicted some unconventional nanostructures, such as patch-, Janus-, peanut-, disk- and snowman-like particles via MC simulations.

The effect of the kind of stabilizers on the formation of "onionlike" multilayered polystyrene-block-poly(Me methacrylate) (PS-b-PMMA) particles was studied. The release of toluene from PS-b-PMMA/toluene droplets dispersed in aq. medium resulted in the formation of onionlike multilayered structures in the particles for all stabilizers used. However, the surface compn. of the particles was strongly affected by the kind of stabilizer. When sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS) and poly(vinyl alc.) (PVA) were used as stabilizers, the surface of the particles was occupied by PMMA phase. On the other hand, in the cases of Emulgen 911 (polyoxyethylene nonylphenyl ether) and Tween 80 (polyoxyethylene sorbitan monooleate) as stabilizers, the PS phase occupied the surfaces. These results for SDS, PVA, and Emulgen 911 are consistent with the surface layer of the PS-b-PMMA particles being occupied by the polymer phase, which gives a lower interfacial tension than that of another phase. However, in the case of Tween 80, interfacial tensions between water and toluene solns. of the polymer showed almost the same values making it impossible to predict the surface polymer phase.

A review. Confined assembly of block copolymers (BCPs) is receiving increasing attention due to the ability to create unconventional morphologies that cannot be obsd. in the corresponding bulk systems. This effect is further driven by the simplicity and versatility of these procedures for controlling the shape of particles prepd. by 3D soft confinement of BCPs in emulsions. By taking advantage of a mobile emulsion interface, the one-step formation of nonspherical BCP particles through spontaneous deformation is possible with design principles and theor. models for controlling shape/nanostructure now being established. This Viewpoint highlights strategies for shape tuning of BCP particles, currently accessible shapes, their controllability, and potential application. The emergence of 3D soft confinement of BCPs and related theory is overviewed with a focus on current strategies, types of nonspherical shapes achieved, and structure-property relationships for nonspherical BCP particles. Finally, the applications and future perspectives for these materials are discussed.

Block copolymer (BCP) self-assembly is one of the most versatile concepts for the bottom-up design of functional nanostructures in materials science, nanomedicine and nanotechnol. While BCPs have been extensively studied regarding their microphase sepn. in bulk and the self-assembly in soln., only recently BCPs were investigated for their ability to form internally ordered microparticles. In this review, we discuss two emerging concepts: (i) the microphase sepn. of BCPs in the spherical confinement of evapg. emulsion droplets and (ii) the self-assembly of highly asym. BCPs under concd. conditions. While the first concept yields solid and compact multicompartment microparticles suited for the synthesis of shape-anisotropic nanoparticles, photonic colloids, and actuators, the latter produces highly regular porous microparticles with exceptional interfacial area (BCP cubosomes and hexosomes). Despite distinct differences in the origin of both fields, commonalities in shape and morphol. suggest an underlying formation mechanism that may link both research directions.

While the morphol. behavior of AB diblock copolymers in confinement is fairly well understood, only sporadic examples exist for ABC triblock terpolymers. Considering the more complex morphol. space of terpolymers, a better understanding of their behavior in confinement would be desirable to gain access to a large variety of multicompartment microparticles (MMs). Equal-sized end blocks (.vphi.S â .vphi.T) result in MMs with lamella-lamella (LL) morphol. and a tulip-bulb or pinecone shape, irresp. of .vphi.B. For asym. end blocks (.vphi.S > .vphi.T) at low .vphi.B, prolate ellipsoids develop a hexagonally packed core-shell ring (HCR) morphol., which changes with increasing .vphi.B to a transition structure between HCR and a concentric sphere-in-lamella (CSL) morphol. Further increasing .vphi.B to .vphi.S â .vphi.B at low .vphi.T, the structure transforms entirely to CSL in an onion-like shape. Hierarchical, structurally colored materials offer a wide variety of visual effects that cannot be achieved with std. pigments or dyes. However, their fabrication requires simultaneous control over multiple length-scales. Here we introduce a robust strategy for the fabrication of hierarchical photonic pigments via the confined self-assembly of bottlebrush block copolymers within emulsified microdroplets. The bottlebrush block copolymer self-assembles into highly ordered concentric lamellae, giving rise to a near perfect photonic multilayer in the solid state, with reflectivity up to 100%. The reflected color can be readily tuned across the whole visible spectrum by either altering the mol. wt. or by blending the bottlebrush block copolymers. Furthermore, the developed photonic pigments are responsive, with a selective and reversible color change obsd. upon swelling in different solvents. Our system is particularly suited for the scalable prodn. of photonic pigments, arising from their rapid self-assembly mechanism and size-independent color.

The authors have characterized the adsorption of a spiropyran-modified cationic surfactant at the silica/aq. soln. interface and the subsequent photoresponsive nature of the adsorbed mol. assemblies. The surfactant used in this study was 1'(6-trimethylammoniohexyl)-3'3'-dimethyl-6-nitrospiro-(2H-1-benzopyran-2,2'-indoline) bromide (SP-Me-6). Visible light incident to the aq. soln. of SP-Me-6 results in the isomerization from the merocyanine (MC) form to the spiro (SP) form, whereas the isomerized SP form reverts to the MC form when the surfactant soln. is stored in the dark. The adsorption isotherms on colloidal silica particles reveal that the combination of electrostatic and intermol. hydrophobic interactions drives the adsorption for both of the isomers, and the more hydrophobic SP form gives a greater adsorbed amt. when compared with the zwitterionic MC form. In situ at. force microscopy (AFM) demonstrated that disklike or flattened spherical surface aggregates are formed in the adsorption plateau region on a flat silica plate, where the SP form gives larger surface aggregates as a result of its greater hydrophobic/associative character. Such a difference in the hydrophobic/associative nature between the two isomers induces reversible changes in the dispersion stability of silica suspensions as well as in the surface force, in response to the photoisomerization. By taking the in situ and ex situ color changes into consideration, it seems likely that the photoisomerization occurs reversibly even after surfactant adsorption on silica.

Light-induced shape transformations represent a fundamental step towards the emergence of adaptive materials exhibiting photomech. behaviors. Although a range of covalent azobenzene-based photoactive materials has been demonstrated, the use of dynamic photoisomerization in mesostructured soft solids involving non-covalent co-assembly has received little attention. Here we prep. discrete micrometre-sized hydrated particles of a hexagonally ordered polyelectrolyte-surfactant mesophase based on the electrostatically induced co-assembly of poly(sodium acrylate) (PAA) and trans-azobenzene trimethylammonium bromide (trans-azoTAB), and demonstrate unusual non-equil. substrate-mediated shape transformations to complex multipodal microarchitectures under continuous blue light. The microparticles spontaneously sequester mol. dyes, functional enzymes and oligonucleotides, and undergo self-division when transformed to the cis state under UV irradn. Our results illustrate that weak bonding interactions in polyelectrolyte-azobenzene surfactant mesophases can be exploited for photo-induced long-range mol. motion, and highlight how dynamic shape transformations and autonomous division can be activated by spatially confining azobenzene photomechanics in condensed microparticulate materials.

Self-assembled monolayers of a 6-nitro BIPS spiropyran (SP) modified with a disulfide-terminated aliph. chain were prepd. on polycryst. gold surfaces and characterized by UV/vis absorption, surface-enhanced Raman scattering (SERS), and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopies (XPS). The SAMs obtained are composed of the ring-closed form (i.e., spiropyran) only. Irradn. with UV light results in conversion of the monolayer to the merocyanine form (MC), manifested in the appearance of an N+ contribution in the N 1s region of the XPS spectrum of the SAMs, the characteristic absorption band of the MC form in the visible region at 555 nm, and the C-O stretching band in the SERS spectrum. Recovery of the initial state of the monolayer was obsd. both thermally and after irradn. with visible light. Several switching cycles were performed and monitored by SERS spectroscopy, demonstrating the stability of the SAMs during repeated switching between SP and MC states. A key finding in the present study is that ring-opening of the surface-immobilized spiropyrans can be induced by irradn. with continuous wave NIR (785 nm) light as well as by irradn. with UV light. We demonstrate that ring-opening by irradn. at 785 nm proceeds by a two-photon absorption pathway both in the SAMs and in the solid state. Hence, spiropyran SAMs on gold can undergo reversible photochem. switching from the SP to the MC form with both UV and NIR and the reverse reaction induced by irradn. with visible light or heating. Furthermore, the observation of NIR-induced switching with a continuous wave source holds important consequences in the study of photochromic switches on surfaces using SERS and emphasizes the importance of the use of multiple complementary techniques in characterizing photoresponsive SAMs.

Two-dimensional (2D) nanosheets are a class of fascinating host material that demonstrates a high sp. surface area for the immobilization of functional mols. Herein, we describe a layered photochromic film using montmorillonite 2D nanosheets immobilized with spiropyran units, which demonstrates a remarkable and reversible photochromic behavior. The synthesis of the layered photochromic film includes the intercalation and exfoliation of montmorillonite powders into 2D nanosheets using a spiropyran-modified surfactant and a subsequent vacuum filtration. The photochromic units of spiropyran-modified quaternary ammonium groups are immobilized on the surface of montmorillonite 2D nanosheets through an electrostatic interaction after exchanging with the native cations in montmorillonite during the intercalation and exfoliation. The photoisomerization of the spiropyran units between closed-ring spiropyran and open-ring merocyanine upon visible/UV irradn. contributes to the photochromic behavior of the layered film. The color contrast between the coloration and decoloration states of photochromic film is optimized by increasing the amt. of spiropyran-modified cationic surfactant during the intercalation and exfoliation process. Our layered films with a visual photochromic behavior may promote their applications for optical data storage, optical switching and chem. sensing.

A review. In the past few years, spiropyran has emerged as the mol. of choice for the construction of novel dynamic materials. This unique mol. switch undergoes structural isomerization in response to a variety of orthogonal stimuli, e.g. light, temp., metal ions, redox potential, and mech. stress. Incorporation of this switch onto macromol. supports or inorg. scaffolds allows for the creation of robust dynamic materials. This review discusses the synthesis, switching conditions and use of dynamic materials in which spiropyran has been attached to the surfaces of polymers, biomacromols., inorg. nanoparticles, as well as solid surfaces. The resulting materials show fascinating properties whereby the state of the switch intimately affects a multitude of useful properties of the support. The utility of the spiropyran switch will undoubtedly endow these materials with far-reaching applications in the near future.

Thermally-induced isomerization of spiropyran derivs. in aq. media has been studied. The colorless spirocyclic (SP) forms of spiropyran derivs. are isomerized to colored merocyanine (MC) forms even in dark conditions at elevated temp. Equil., kinetic, and deuterium expts. reveal that the thermal SP MC isomerization is due to the stabilization of MC form by a hydrogen bonding interaction with water mols. This leads to the ground state energy of the MC form decreasing to lower than that of the SP form, resulting in SP MC isomerization. The thermal isomerization property is applicable to a rough indication of soln. temp. The spiropyran derivs., when dissolved in aq. media under irradn. of visible light with an appropriate light intensity, demonstrate an increase in MC absorbance with a rise in temp. The absorption response occurs reversibly regardless of the heating/cooling sequence. The spiropyran derivs. therefore have a potential for colorimetric temp. indication.

Spirobenzopyrans, which are well known as photochromic compds., exist as thermodynamically stable protonated ring-opened isomers (protonated merocyanine form, McH) in an acidic aq. soln. in the dark. In the present study, we investigated effects of substitution of the spirobenzopyrans on a ring-opening behavior in an aq. system. We prepd. five polymerizable spirobenzopyrans that are substituted with a methoxy group or a nitro group at the 6'- or 8'-positions and without a substituent. These monomers were copolymd. with N,N-dimethylacrylamide to evaluate the spirobenzopyrans in aq. soln. Correlation between ring-opening rates and the kind and position of the substitution can be summarized as follows: the substitution of an electron-donating methoxy group and the substitution at the 8'-position increased the ring-opening rate, whereas the substitution of an electron-withdrawing nitro group decreased the rate. The effects of the substitution can be explained by changes in the electron d. of the oxygen atom of the spirobenzopyrans.

Surface-engineered, 10 nm-sized graphene quantum dots (GQDs) are shown to be efficient surfactants for producing 3-pentadecyl phenol (PDP)-combined poly(styrene-b-4-vinylpyridine) (PS-b-P4VP(PDP)) particles that feature tunable shapes and internal morphologies. The surface properties of GQDs were modified by grafting different alkyl ligands, such as hexylamine and oleylamine, to generate the surfactant behavior of the GQDs. In stark contrast to the behavior of the unmodified GQDs, hexylamine-grafted GQDs and oleylamine-grafted GQD surfactants were selectively positioned on the PS and P4VP(PDP) domains, resp., at the surface of the particles. This positioning effectively tuned the interfacial interaction between two different PS/P4VP(PDP) domains of the particles and the surrounding water during emulsification and induced a dramatic morphol. transition to convex lens-shaped particles. Precise and systematic control of interfacial activity of GQD surfactants was also demonstrated by varying the d. of the alkyl ligands on the GQDs. The excellent surface tunability of 10 nm-sized GQDs combined with their significant optical and elec. properties highlight their importance as surfactants for producing colloidal particles with novel functions.

Meanwhile, the embedding of spiropyran inside the micelles produces effects of conformational constraint and uncontact to solvent. The synergy of the above three effects significantly enhances the fluorescence emission of the micelles in colloidal dispersion whereas in the case of the pure spiropyran it shows virtually no emission in toluene. With the aid of UV and daylight, the fluorescent micelles dramatically shows light-induced size tunability and excellent recyclability, corresponding to the significant change in polarity of the copolymer chain that is caused by the reversible transformation between weak polar spiropyran and zwitterionic merocyanine. Loading and controlled release of rhodamine 6G as a typical polar drug substance is successfully achieved with the micelles. These exptl. results may bring about more promising applications of spiropyran species beyond their photochromic properties in microscopic fields such as nanocarrier for drug delivery or micro detector for biosensor.

Shape and morphol. of polymeric particles are of great importance in controlling their optical properties or self-assembly into unusual superstructures. Confinement of block copolymers (BCPs) in evaporative emulsions affords particles with diverse structures, including prolate ellipsoids, onion-like spheres, oblate ellipsoids, and others. Herein, we report that the evapn. rate of solvent from emulsions encapsulating sym. polystyrene-b-polybutadiene (PS-b-PB) dets. the shape and internal nanostructure of micron-sized BCP particles. A distinct morphol. transition from the ellipsoids with striped lamellae to the onion-like spheres was obsd. with decreasing evapn. rate. Expts. and dissipative particle dynamics (DPD) simulations showed that the evapn. rate affected the organization of BCPs at the particle surface, which detd. the final shape and internal nanostructure of the particles. Differences in the solvent diffusion rates in PS and PB at rapid evapn. rates induced alignment of both domains perpendicular to the particle surface, resulting in ellipsoids with axial lamellar stripes. Slower evapn. rates provided sufficient time for BCP organization into onion-like structures with PB as the outermost layer, owing to the preferential interaction of PB with the surrounding. BCP mol. wt. was found to influence the crit. evapn. rate corresponding to the morphol. transition from ellipsoid to onion-like particles, as well as the ellipsoid aspect ratio. DPD simulations produced morphologies remarkably similar to those obtained from expts., thus elucidated the mechanism and driving forces responsible for the evapn.-induced assembly of BCPs into particles with well-defined shapes and morphologies.

Reversible chromism of spiropyran in the cavity of a flexible coordination cage
Samanta Dipak; Gemen Julius; Klajn Rafal; Galaktionova Daria; Kral Petr; Shimon Linda J W; Diskin-Posner Yael; Avram Liat; Kral Petr; Kral Petr

Confining molecules to volumes only slightly larger than the molecules themselves can profoundly alter their properties. Molecular switches-entities that can be toggled between two or more forms upon exposure to an external stimulus-often require conformational freedom to isomerize. Therefore, placing these switches in confined spaces can render them non-operational. To preserve the switchability of these species under confinement, we work with a water-soluble coordination cage that is flexible enough to adapt its shape to the conformation of the encapsulated guest. We show that owing to its flexibility, the cage is not only capable of accommodating-and solubilizing in water-several light-responsive spiropyran-based molecular switches, but, more importantly, it also provides an environment suitable for the efficient, reversible photoisomerization of the bound guests. Our findings pave the way towards studying various molecular switching processes in confined environments.

Six water-sol. spiropyran derivs. have been characterized with respect to the thermal and photoinduced reactions over a broad pH-interval. A comprehensive kinetic model was formulated including the spiro- and the merocyanine isomers, the resp. protonated forms, and the hydrolysis products. The exptl. studies on the hydrolysis reaction mechanism were supplemented by calcns. using quantum mech. (QM) models employing d. functional theory. The results show that (1) the substitution pattern dramatically influences the pKa-values of the protonated forms as well as the rates of the thermal isomerization reactions, (2) water is the nucleophile in the hydrolysis reaction around neutral pH, (3) the phenolate oxygen of the merocyanine form plays a key role in the hydrolysis reaction. Hence, the nonprotonated merocyanine isomer is susceptible to hydrolysis, whereas the corresponding protonated form is stable toward hydrolytic degrdn.

Polymer nanoparticles of 40-400 nm diam. with spiropyran-merocyanine dyes incorporated into their hydrophobic cavities have been prepd.; in contrast to their virtually nonfluorescent character in most environments, the merocyanine forms of the encapsulated dyes are highly fluorescent. Spiro-mero photoisomerization is reversible, allowing the fluorescence to be switched "on" and "off" by alternating UV and visible light. Immobilizing the dye inside hydrophobic pockets of nanoparticles also improves its photostability, rendering it more resistant than the same dyes in soln. to fatigue effects arising from photochem. switching. The photophys. characteristics of the encapsulated fluorophores differ dramatically from those of the same species in soln., making nanoparticle-protected hydrophobic fluorophores attractive materials for potential applications such as optical data storage and switching and biol. fluorescent labeling. To evaluate the potential for biol. tagging, these optically addressable nanoparticles have been delivered into living cells and imaged with a liq. nitrogen-cooled CCD.

Here, we report a novel polymeric nanoparticle prepd. by the self-assembly of amphiphilic copolymers contg. a fluorescent naphthalimide (NAPH) and a photochromic spiropyran (SP), which possesses reversibly photoswitchable dual-color fluorescence and controlled release properties. The amphiphilic copolymers were synthesized by incorporating NAPH and SP into Me ether poly(ethylene glycol)-poly(Î²-amino esters) (MPEG-PAE) via quaternization. The nanoparticles would change between yellow and purple reversibly upon UV and visible light irradn. because of the photoisomerization between SP and merocyanine (MC). The corresponding fluorescence would be switched between green and orange-red reversibly upon blue light excitation through the fluorescence resonance energy transfer from the excited NAPH to the photoisomerized MC. Meanwhile, the prepd. spherical nanoparticles could be swollen under UV irradn. as the hydrophobic SP isomerized to hydrophilic MC; the nanoparticles could also be swollen under acidic conditions because of the protonation of the amino groups of PAE. Upon UV light irradn. and acidic stimulation, the cargoes, hydrophobic Coumarin 102, encapsulated in the nanoparticles would be released. The prepd. nanoparticles, which exhibit not only excellent reversible dual-color fluorescence properties but also prominent controlled release performance, will open up new possibilities for the combined application of fluorescence imaging and controlled release.

Suppression of the coffee-ring effect by shape-dependent capillary interactions
Yunker, Peter J.; Still, Tim; Lohr, Matthew A.; Yodh, A. G.
